awd_titl_txt: RUI: Strongly Nonlinear Dynamics of Lattice Networks: From Analysis to Application
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop analytical, computational, and experimental tools for the study of a particular class of lattice networks. Of particular interest in this research are the dynamics of localization and time-periodicity, which can be exploited for a variety of applications including vibration energy harvesting. Through the geometry of the network and the nonlinear nature of the connecting elements, extremely rich dynamics can be observed and verified by experimental data provided by collaborations with engineering laboratories. The results could be used to develop broadband resonators that are powered through ambient vibrations, with the goal of significantly reducing battery usage.

The models under study in this project have the form of a two-dimensional nonlinear coupled oscillator, where the coupling is described by a power-law. Closed-form analytical expressions for solutions of these equations are not available, and thus the theoretical study of the system will concern analytical approximations and numerical computation.  Multiscale methods will be used to derive modulation equations to describe spatially localized and time-periodic solutions, and error bounds for these approximations will be explored. In parametric regions where the derived analytical approximations are not valid, numerical computations will be employed. Three case examples are considered for experimental realizations: granular crystals, repelling magnets, and origami unit cells. An energy harvesting concept based on a magnetic lattice network will be designed, optimized, implemented, and benchmarked.

por.por_cntn:
When working with complicated models it is often useful to look for solutions with special properties. For example, a solution that repeats a pattern periodically in time and that has most of its energy concentrated in one area is called a "breather".  Breathers can be found in many types of physical systems. The systems of particular interest to this project are nonlinear lattices, which are chains of particles that interact with each other in a nonlinear fashion. For this project, computational, analytical and experimental tools were developed in order to study breathers in a variety of nonlinear lattices. Since energy is concentrated within a breather,  breather formation could be beneficial for the application of energy harvesting. This is because as a breather forms energy is transferred through the lattice, accumulating mostly at one node. The mechanical energy at this node can then be converted to electrical energy using existing technology (such as piezoelectric materials). The project explored the possibility of harvesting energy using breathers. Thus, the project contributed toward larger picture societal goals by contributing to the field of energy harvesting, since efficient energy harvesters could be used in place of batteries. 

The PI integrated research and education at several levels of the undergraduate experience. This includes (i) interaction with first years students in a summer orientation via a project he designed involving modeling and computer simulation (ii)  a work-study program where students learned Matlab programing, LaTeX typesetting, and ran simulations on a high performance cluster to generate data that appeared in publications (iii) using data and modeling on energy harvesting in several courses (iv) advising summer research experiences for eight students. At all levels the PI encouraged participation from students traditionally underrepresented in the sciences.
Results of the research were disseminated to the scientific community via presentations at international conferences and outreach efforts were made via several student talks and a public lecture.
